Fuel Protests Slow Britain, As Blair Appeals for an End Prime Minister Tony Blair called on protesters angered by high fuel taxes to lift their virtual siege of oil refineries and storage depots, saying their actions were paralyzing the country and endangering lives.
Truckers and farmers throughout continental Europe continued their protests, though political leaders mostly dug in their heels against cuts in gasoline taxes.

McDonald's Foe Convicted Jose Bove, the French farmer who became something of a national hero last year for leading an attack on a McDonald's restaurant after the United States levied high tariffs on luxury food imported from the European Union, was convicted of criminal vandalism and sentenced to three months in prison.

China Trade Bill Advances Senators rejected a contentious amendment to impose sanctions on Chinese companies that export advanced weapons to hostile nations, clearing the last major hurdle to passing the landmark trade bill.

Further Review of Chile Files The White House ordered a new look at several hundred files that the C.I.A. intends to withhold when it releases American documents about the military coup in Chile in 1973. The national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said he wanted the ''fullest possible disclosure.''

End to Russian Treason Case The Russian Supreme Court rebuffed a final government plea to reopen the treason case against Aleksandr Nikitin, left, a former naval captain who gave nuclear opponents details of radioactive pollution by Russian submarines.

Terror Bombing in Indonesia A car bomb exploded in the parking garage of the Indonesian Stock Exchange, killing at least 13 people and wounding dozens in the latest unexplained bombing in recent weeks in Jakarta and other cities. The blast came shortly before the corruption trial of former President Suharto was to resume.

Scientist Pleads Guilty And Is Freed, With Apology The former Los Alamos scientist Wen Ho Lee pleaded guilty to a single charge of mishandling nuclear secrets and left federal court a free man with an apology from Judge James A. Parker, who angrily accused administration officials of abusing their power and misleading him to think that Dr. Lee posed a threat to national security.
Democratic Funds Inquiry Federal campaign finance investigators are looking into the way the Democratic National Committee has raised money from trial lawyers.

More Criticism for Hollywood Democrats and Republicans alike, appearing at a Senate Commerce Committee hearing called by Senator John McCain, scored the entertainment industry for marketing violent entertainment to children.

Second Thoughts on Tax Cuts Many Congressional Republicans believe the across-the-board tax cut pushed by Gov. George W. Bush does not aid their races and they have adopted a strategy emphasizing debt reduction and bite-size cuts.
Marriage-Penalty Veto Intact The House failed to achieve the two-thirds majority needed to override President Clinton's veto of the marriage-penalty tax relief bill.

Symbolic Support for Hate Bill The House, voting 232 to 192 on a procedural question, endorsed a legislative amendment that would make attacks on gays a federal hate crime. But Senate leaders said the amendment would not survive.
Airline Rudder Change The F.A.A. plans to require replacement of Boeing 737 rudder-control systems and new procedures for dealing with rudder problems.
Design for King Memorial ROMA Design Group of San Francisco was chosen to design the Washington memorial to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

Suits Over Ritalin Lawyers filed class-action lawsuits against a drug maker and a professional group, saying they had conspired to create a market for the drug widely used to treat children with attention deficit disorder.

Lazio and Mrs. Clinton Meet in First Debate Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio assailed each other for nearly 60 minutes in a televised debate, questioning each other's credentials, integrity and political views. Near the end, Mr. Lazio approached the first lady and unsuccessfully challenged her to sign a pledge renouncing soft money.

Challenger May Prevail Regina Seltzer, 71, a former librarian who became a lawyer and now practices pro bono environmental law, appeared to have defeated Representative Michael P. Forbes of Long Island by 39 votes for the Democratic nomination for his seat.

Inquiry Into Tainted Water Three people in Manhattan were treated at hospitals this month and last after drinking three different brands of bottled water that the police said were contaminated with an ammonia-like substance. Mayor Giuliani and officials of the New York Police Department and the F.B.I. said they were investigating.

Adventure Racers Stricken The federal Centers for Disease Control said that at least 30 of the 155 Americans who participated in the Eco-Challenge expedition race in Malaysian Borneo that ended Sept. 1 had contracted a potentially deadly bacterial infection, leptospirosis, and that many had been hospitalized.
New Apple Operating System Apple issued a beta version of its Mac OS X (10) operating system software, its first fundamentally new operating system since 1984.

U.S. Delays Europe Sanctions President Clinton delayed new punitive duties on European luxury goods after an appeal from Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, who shifted his position on two trade issues -- bananas and taxes -- to help the United States. Mr. Blair also warned that the duties might do more harm than good to the United States' strained trade relations with Europe.

Reasoning Behind Chase Deal Chase Manhattan announced its plans to acquire J. P. Morgan for $30.9 billion in stock, citing the combination of Chase's broad base of customers with Morgan's exclusive clientele and financial expertise.

Marketing and Public Schools A General Accounting Office study found corporate marketing in public schools rising sharply, though few states have laws to address the phenomenon and most decisions on commercial arrangements in schools are made piecemeal by local officials.
Editorials: A fierce opening debate; gigantic banks, evocative names; two countries under one banner; movie theaters seek happy ending. Columns: Bob Herbert, William Safire.
